newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu, Arafat hold summit, commit to peace.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu, Arafat hold summit, commit to peace.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat held their first summit on Wednesday, promising to pursue peace together.

But the hour-long meeting at the Israel-Gaza border began awkwardly with a brief handshake too quick to photograph and did not resolve main sticking points: the date and scope of Israel's long-delayed troop redeployment in the West Bank city of Hebron.
An Israeli-Palestinian steering committee will begin meeting on Thursday to tackle that issue and others, Terje Larsen, the U.N.'s top official in the self-ruled West Bank and Gaza, told reporters.
"I believe that we will work with Mr Bibi (Netanyahu) and his government to push the peace process, the peace of the brave," Arafat said.

"Both parties reiterate their commitment to the interim agreement and their determination to carry out its implementation," Netanyahu said, referring to self-rule deals between the previous Israeli government and the PLO.

But he told a news conference: "We have to take into account the needs and requirements of both sides on the basis of reciprocity and the assurance of the security and well-being of both Israelis and Palestinians alike."

Reciprocity is the term Netanyahu uses to make implementation of past peace deals conditional on an end to what he has termed Palestinian violations of the accords, especially alleged self-rule activity in Jerusalem, a city Israel controls.
By security, Netanyahu means protection for the 400 Jewish settlers living among more than 100,000 Arabs in Hebron.
Protecting them, Israeli officials have said, entails revising the troop redeployment set in a 1995 agreement, something Palestinians have opposed.
Netanyahu's spokesman Shai Bazak said the decision to discuss Hebron further "clarifies to the Palestinians...that the issue is not yet closed".

Arafat appeared to be content with the victory Palestinian officials said he achieved by getting a reluctant Netanyahu to meet him, and gave a muted response when asked at the news conference about the Hebron issue.
"I have nothing to add but to state that we will continue to negotiate and to coordinate all efforts, by all means," Arafat said.

"The road is paved for the negotiations between us on all aspects and at every level, including the final-status talks, of course," he said. But Palestinian officials said from their perspective the talks were on implementation rather than changing previous accords.

Israeli and Palestinian negotiators, with the help of Larsen, a Norwegian middleman who helped broker the original Oslo self-rule accord in 1993, had struggled over the past week to find a formula for a summit and full-scale peace talks.
Netanyahu's agreement to meet Arafat followed some tough talk and strident action from the Palestinian leader.
Arafat said last week's Israeli decision to expand Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza and its policy on Jerusalem were tantamount to declaring war on the Palestinians.
He also called a four-hour general strike in the two areas last Thursday, the first such stoppage in two years.
Netanyahu and Arafat started the meeting at the Israel-Gaza border with a quick handshake that caught photographers off-guard.
They shook hands again -- this time for four seconds -- as cameras clicked but ignored shouted appeals from photographers at the end of their news conference for another replay.
The meeting followed four days of round-the-clock talks to fix a summit seen as vital to reviving peace talks suspended since Islamic suicide bombers killed 59 people in Israel in February and March.
In Israel's May election, Netanyahu ousted Prime Minister Shimon Peres who in November succeeded Yitzhak Rabin, assassinated by a Jew opposed to peace moves with the Palestinians.
Netanyahu, elected in May on a vow to take a hard line in peace talks with the Palestinians, had said originally he preferred not to meet Arafat but softened his position in recent days.
